title: matrimony
descriptions: the state of being married : MARRIAGE
sentences: After years of friendship, they decided to enter into matrimony with a simple ceremony at the local chapel.
Matrimony is a lifelong commitment that they were both ready to embrace wholeheartedly.

title: submissive
descriptions: submitting to others
sentences: The submissive dog immediately lay down at its owner's feet.
In the debate, he adopted a submissive stance, agreeing with every point made by his opponent.

title: proclaim
descriptions: to declare publicly, typically insistently, proudly, or defiantly and in either speech or writing : ANNOUNCE
to declare or declare to be solemnly, officially, or formally
sentences: The mayor will proclaim the start of the festival with a speech at noon.
She was eager to proclaim her success after months of hard work.

title: imperious
descriptions: marked by arrogant assurance : DOMINEERING
intensely compelling : URGENT
sentences: His imperious demand left no room for negotiation.
The imperious leader expected his orders to be followed without question.

title: bewildering
descriptions: extremely confusing or difficult to understand
sentences: The magician's act was so bewildering that the audience couldn't figure out how he did his tricks.
Facing a bewildering array of choices, she found it hard to make a decision.

title: scribble
descriptions: to write or draw hastily or carelessly
to fill or cover something with careless or worthless writings or drawings
sentences: The child liked to scribble in her notebook during class.
Amidst his notes, he would often scribble reminders to himself.

title: aberrant
descriptions: deviating from the usual or natural type : ATYPICAL, ABNORMAL
straying from the right or normal way
sentences: The scientist noted the aberrant behavior of the cells under a new drug.
Aberrant weather patterns this year have led to an unusually long rainy season.

title: rejoice
descriptions: to feel joy or great delight
sentences: The whole family rejoiced at the news of his safe return.
After the final whistle, the players rejoiced in their hard-fought victory.

title: consternation
descriptions: amazement or dismay that hinders or throws into confusion
sentences: The sudden change in policy caused consternation among the employees.
To her consternation, she found the door locked from the inside.

title: interrogate
descriptions: to question formally and systematically
to give or send out a signal to (a device, such as a transponder) for triggering an appropriate response
sentences: The detective needed to interrogate the suspect to gather more information.
In an attempt to understand the problem, she interrogated the data with a series of complex queries.

title: bicker
descriptions: petulant quarreling : ALTERCATION
to engage in a petulant or petty quarrel
to move with a rapidly repeated noise
sentences: The children would often bicker over trivial matters, much to their parents' annoyance.
Despite their occasional bickering, they were the best of friends.

title: feign
descriptions: to give a false appearance of : induce as a false impression
sentences: He tried to feign innocence but the smile on his face gave him away.
To avoid the meeting, she would feign illness.

title: convey
descriptions: to bear from one place to another
to cause to pass from one place or person to another
sentences: The teacher used examples to convey the complex concepts to the students.
He conveyed his intentions through a carefully crafted letter.

title: ordeal
descriptions: a primitive means used to determine guilt or innocence by submitting the accused to dangerous or painful tests believed to be under supernatural control
sentences: Surviving in the wilderness was an ordeal they would never forget.
The marathon was an ordeal that tested her physical and mental strength.

title: pertain
descriptions: to belong as a part, member, accessory, or product
to have reference
sentences: The laws pertain to the protection of endangered species.
The documents pertaining to the case were submitted to the court.

title: seam
descriptions: the joining of two pieces (as of cloth or leather) by sewing usually near the edge
the space between adjacent planks or strakes of a ship
a weak or vulnerable area or gap
sentences: The seam of her dress came undone just before the performance.
He carefully sealed the seam between the windows to prevent drafts.

title: leverage
descriptions: the action of a lever or the mechanical advantage gained by it
the use of credit to enhance one's speculative capacity
sentences: She used her network to leverage support for the project.
In negotiations, it's important to have leverage.

title: degenerate
descriptions: having declined or become less specialized (as in nature, character, structure, or function) from an ancestral or former state
sentences: The discussion quickly degenerated into an argument.
Without exercise, the muscles will degenerate over time.

title: confidential
descriptions: intended for or restricted to the use of a particular person, group, or class : PRIVATE, SECRET
sentences: He shared confidential information during the meeting.
The documents were marked as confidential.

title: subsidiary
descriptions: furnishing aid or support : AUXILIARY
sentences: The corporation has several subsidiary companies.
She works for a subsidiary of a well-known tech company.

title: asunder
descriptions: into parts
apart from each other
sentences: The explosion tore the ship asunder.
Their once close friendship had been torn asunder by lies.

title: demise
descriptions: a cessation of existence or activity
the conveyance of an estate
sentences: The company faced its demise after a series of unfortunate decisions.
News of the old king's demise spread quickly throughout the kingdom.

title: callous
descriptions: being hardened and thickened
feeling no emotion
sentences: His callous remarks about the poor shocked many.
She had become callous to the suffering of others.

title: reconcile
descriptions: to restore to friendship or harmony
to make consistent or congruous
sentences: After a long dispute, the siblings managed to reconcile and mend their relationship.
It's difficult to reconcile the need for economic development with environmental protection.

title: nominal
descriptions: of, relating to, or being a noun or a word or expression taking a noun construction
existing or being something in name or form only
sentences: He holds a nominal position in the company, with no actual authority.
The fee is nominal, barely covering the cost of materials.

title: forlorn
descriptions: sad and lonely because of isolation or desertion : DESOLATE
being in poor condition : MISERABLE, WRETCHED
sentences: The abandoned house looked forlorn and haunted.
She felt forlorn after her friends left the city.

title: infamy
descriptions: evil reputation brought about by something grossly criminal, shocking, or brutal
sentences: The dictator's reign was marked by infamy and terror.
The pirate's infamy spread across the seven seas.

title: alacrity
descriptions: promptness in response : cheerful readiness
sentences: She accepted the invitation with alacrity, excited for the adventure.
His alacrity to help others was well-known in the community.

title: varnish
descriptions: a liquid preparation that when applied to a surface dries to form a hard lustrous typically transparent coating
sentences: The carpenter applied a layer of varnish to protect the wood.
Under the varnish, the old painting revealed its true colors.

title: premise
descriptions: a proposition antecedently supposed or proved as a basis of argument or inference
something assumed or taken for granted : PRESUPPOSITION
sentences: The argument was based on the faulty premise that all opinions are equal.
The business plan's premise was innovative, attracting many investors.

title: hinder
descriptions: to make slow or difficult the progress of : HAMPER
to hold back : PREVENT, CHECK
sentences: The heavy rain hindered their travel plans.
Lack of resources hindered the project's progress.

title: exalt
descriptions: to raise in rank, power, or character
to elevate by praise or in estimation : GLORIFY
sentences: The poet sought to exalt the beauty of nature through his verses.
Heroes are exalted for their bravery and selflessness.

title: recondite
descriptions: difficult or impossible for one of ordinary understanding or knowledge to comprehend : DEEP
sentences: The professor's lecture on quantum physics was so recondite that few could follow.
Her taste in music was recondite, favoring obscure and complex compositions.

title: entangle
descriptions: to wrap or twist together : INTERWEAVE
to involve in a perplexing or troublesome situation
sentences: The case became more complex as new evidence entangled it further.
Trying to avoid the issue, he only became more entangled in lies.

title: prospect
descriptions: the act of looking forward : ANTICIPATION
sentences: The prospect of moving to a new city filled her with excitement.
Miners arrived in the area, lured by the prospect of finding gold.

title: debase
descriptions: to lower in status, esteem, quality, or character
to reduce the intrinsic value of (a coin) by increasing the base-metal content
sentences: The politician's scandal served to debase his reputation among voters.
Counterfeiting money debases the currency and harms the economy.

title: venerable
descriptions: calling forth respect through age, character, and attainments
made sacred especially by religious or historical association
sentences: The venerable oak tree has stood in the village square for centuries.
She is considered a venerable leader in the community for her wisdom and kindness.

title: unscathed
descriptions: wholly unharmed : not injured
sentences: Despite the severe storm, the ship arrived at the harbor unscathed.
He emerged unscathed from the accident, much to everyone's relief.

title: frown
descriptions: to contract the brow in displeasure or concentration
to give evidence of displeasure or disapproval by or as if by facial expression
sentences: His mother frowned at the mess he had made in the kitchen.
She couldn't help but frown upon hearing the disappointing news.

title: occlude
descriptions: to close up or block off : OBSTRUCT
sentences: A blood clot can occlude an artery, leading to serious health issues.
The thick fog occluded her vision as she drove through the mountains.

title: gullible
descriptions: easily duped or cheated
sentences: The con artist found a gullible victim willing to invest in his fraudulent scheme.
His gullible nature made him an easy target for pranks at the office.

title: preempt
descriptions: to seize upon to the exclusion of others : take for oneself
to replace with something considered to be of greater value or priority : take precedence over
sentences: The governor's announcement was designed to preempt any public panic.
To preempt competition, the company released its product ahead of schedule.

title: elongate
descriptions: to extend the length of
to grow in length
sentences: She used a special lens to elongate the appearance of the room in her photograph.
The shadows began to elongate as the sun set.

title: relinquish
descriptions: to withdraw or retreat from : leave behind
to stop holding physically : RELEASE
sentences: He had to relinquish his claim to the throne after the scandal.
Reluctantly, she relinquished her hold on the old letters, throwing them into the fire.

title: bound
descriptions: fastened by or as if by a band : CONFINED
placed under legal or moral restraint or obligation : OBLIGED
sentences: The prisoner was bound by heavy chains.
She felt bound by her promise to keep the secret.

title: behest
descriptions: an authoritative order : COMMAND
an urgent prompting
sentences: At the king's behest, the gates were opened to the refugees.
She organized the event at the behest of the community leader.

title: debilitate
descriptions: to impair the strength of : ENFEEBLE
sentences: The illness debilitated him to the point where he could barely stand.
A debilitated economy struggles to recover from such a comprehensive downturn.

title: caveat
descriptions: a warning enjoining one from certain acts or practices
an explanation to prevent misinterpretation
sentences: He agreed to the deal, but with the caveat that he'd be paid upfront.
The only caveat to using the community pool is that residents must clean up after themselves.

title: retain
descriptions: to keep in possession or use
to hold secure or intact
sentences: She has an amazing ability to retain information after reading it just once.
The company decided to retain some of the older features in the new model.

title: poignant
descriptions: painfully affecting the feelings : PIERCING
pleasurably stimulating
sentences: The movie's poignant ending left the audience in tears.
Her poignant words about the importance of kindness resonated with everyone.

title: resonate
descriptions: to relate harmoniously : strike a chord
sentences: The speaker's message on environmental conservation resonated with the young audience.
The sound of the bell resonated through the empty hall.

title: divulge
descriptions: to make known (something, such as a confidence or secret)
sentences: He refused to divulge the secrets of the magic trick.
The company will not divulge its sales figures until the end of the quarter.

title: agitate
descriptions: to excite and often trouble the mind or feelings of : DISTURB
to discuss excitedly and earnestly
sentences: The unfair decision agitated the crowd, leading to loud protests.
She became agitated when she couldn't find her keys.

title: ponder
descriptions: to weigh in the mind : APPRAISE
to think about : reflect on
sentences: He sat by the window, pondering his future.
She pondered over the problem for hours, trying to find a solution.

title: superfluous
descriptions: exceeding what is sufficient or necessary : EXTRA
not needed : UNNECESSARY
sentences: The report was filled with superfluous details that distracted from the main point.
In a minimalist lifestyle, anything superfluous is eliminated to focus on the essentials.

title: budding
descriptions: being in an early stage of development
sentences: The budding artist displayed her paintings at the local gallery for the first time.
Spring is a beautiful season, with trees budding and flowers blooming.

title: bruit
descriptions: REPORT, RUMOR
sentences: Rumors about the merger were bruited about the office.
The villagers bruited the arrival of a mysterious stranger.

title: blatant
descriptions: noisy especially in a vulgar or offensive manner : CLAMOROUS
completely obvious, conspicuous, or obtrusive especially in a crass or offensive manner : BRAZEN
sentences: His blatant disregard for the rules got him into trouble.
The blatant lie was obvious to everyone in the room.

title: indict
descriptions: to charge with a crime by the finding or presentment of a jury (such as a grand jury) in due form of law
to charge with a fault or offense : CRITICIZE, ACCUSE
sentences: The grand jury indicted the mayor on charges of corruption.
After much investigation, the businessman was indicted for fraud.

title: throes
descriptions: a hard or painful struggle
sentences: The country was in the throes of economic collapse.
She was in the throes of making a difficult decision that could change her life.

title: omnipotence
descriptions: an agency or force of unlimited power
sentences: In many religions, God is described as having omnipotence.
The dictator's desire for omnipotence led to his downfall.

title: distill
descriptions: to let fall, exude, or precipitate in drops or in a wet mist
to purify or transform (a liquid) by successive evaporation and condensation
sentences: The process to distill water involves heating it to create vapor and then condensing the vapor back into liquid.
She managed to distill the essence of her argument into a few concise sentences.

title: extol
descriptions: to praise highly : GLORIFY
sentences: Critics extol the movie for its groundbreaking special effects and narrative.
He would often extol the virtues of patience and hard work.

title: combustion
descriptions: an act or instance of burning
a usually rapid chemical process (such as oxidation) that produces heat and usually light
sentences: Combustion engines power most of today's vehicles, converting fuel into motion.
The rapid combustion of the dry brush led to a widespread forest fire.

title: unary
descriptions: having, consisting of, or acting on a single element, item, or component : MONADIC
sentences: In programming, a unary operator, like the increment operator (++), operates on only one operand.
Unary systems can be simpler to analyze due to their single-component nature.

title: digress
descriptions: to turn aside especially from the main subject of attention or course of argument
sentences: During the lecture, the professor would often digress from the main topic to share personal anecdotes.
Let's not digress too far from the agenda of this meeting.

title: divert
descriptions: to turn aside : DEVIATE
sentences: The traffic was diverted to an alternate route due to the parade.
He tried to divert the conversation away from controversial topics.

title: strand
descriptions: the land bordering a body of water : SHORE, BEACH
sentences: After the storm, the ship was stranded on a deserted island.
The documentary strived to strand together various narratives into a cohesive story.

title: transient
descriptions: passing especially quickly into and out of existence
passing through or by a place with only a brief stay or sojourn
affecting something or producing results beyond itself
sentences: The beauty of a sunset is transient, reminding us to cherish the moment.
Transient guests at the hotel often stayed for only one night.

title: chide
descriptions: to speak out in angry or displeased rebuke
to voice disapproval to : reproach in a usually mild and constructive manner : SCOLD
sentences: She chided her dog for barking at the neighbors.
The coach chided the team for their lack of effort during practice.

title: tinker
descriptions: to repair, adjust, or experiment with
sentences: He spent the afternoon tinkering with his car in the garage.
Tinkering with the device, she finally managed to improve its performance.

title: repugnance
descriptions: the quality or fact of being contradictory or inconsistent
an instance of such contradiction or inconsistency
strong dislike, distaste, or antagonism
sentences: She felt a deep repugnance for the injustices she witnessed.
The idea of cheating filled him with repugnance.

title: contend
descriptions: to strive or vie in contest or rivalry or against difficulties
to strive in debate
sentences: She had to contend with numerous challenges to achieve her goals.
The two athletes will contend for the championship title next week.

title: perpetual
descriptions: continuing forever
valid for all time
sentences: The perpetual motion of the waves was mesmerizing to watch.
He complained of perpetual interruptions that hindered his work.

title: accolade
descriptions: a mark of acknowledgment
an expression of praise
a ceremonial embrace
sentences: The novel received accolades from both critics and readers alike.
Winning the award was the highest accolade he had ever received.

title: amicable
descriptions: characterized by friendly goodwill
sentences: Despite the disagreement, the meeting concluded on an amicable note.
They reached an amicable solution to the dispute.

title: refrain
descriptions: to keep oneself from doing, feeling, or indulging in something and especially from following a passing impulse
sentences: Please refrain from making loud noises in the library.
She couldn't refrain from smiling when she saw the puppy.

title: imminent
descriptions: ready to take place : happening soon
sentences: Everyone was tense, sensing that a storm was imminent.
The project's completion is imminent, likely within the next week.

title: perpetuate
descriptions: cause to last indefinitely
sentences: Misunderstandings can perpetuate conflict if not addressed properly.
The film sought to perpetuate the memory of the hero.

title: coddle
descriptions: to cook (something, such as eggs) in liquid slowly and gently just below the boiling point
to treat with extreme or excessive care or kindness
sentences: She was often criticized for coddling her children too much.
You shouldn't coddle the plants; they need to adapt to the environment.

title: pernicious
descriptions: highly injurious or destructive : DEADLY
sentences: The pernicious weed spread throughout the farmland, choking the life out of the crops.
He warned of the pernicious effects of pollution on the planet's ecosystems.

title: bleach
descriptions: to remove color or stains from
to make whiter or lighter especially by physical or chemical removal of color
sentences: She used bleach to remove the stubborn stain from her shirt.
Over time, the sun can bleach the color from fabrics left outdoors.

title: abhor
descriptions: to regard with extreme repugnance : to feel hatred or loathing for : LOATHE
sentences: She abhors the idea of wasting food.
The practice is abhorred by many in the community.

title: subvert
descriptions: to overturn or overthrow from the foundation : RUIN
sentences: The plot to subvert the government was uncovered by intelligence agents.
He was accused of attempting to subvert the traditional values.

title: amiable
descriptions: friendly, sociable, and congenial
sentences: His amiable nature made him well-liked among his peers.
An amiable discussion replaced what could have been a heated debate.

title: expedient
descriptions: suitable for achieving a particular end in a given circumstance
characterized by concern with what is opportune
sentences: Choosing the expedient route, he decided to settle the dispute out of court.
It was more expedient to outsource the work than to train new employees.

title: coalesce
descriptions: to grow together
to unite into a whole : FUSE
sentences: Over time, the various theories began to coalesce into a cohesive framework.
The scattered protesters coalesced into a sizable crowd.

title: clamor
descriptions: noisy shouting
a loud continuous noise
insistent public expression (as of support or protest)
sentences: The clamor from the stadium could be heard miles away.
Residents raised a clamor over the proposed new highway.

title: sublime
descriptions: to cause to pass directly from the solid to the vapor state and condense back to solid form
to convert (something inferior) into something of higher worth
sentences: The view from the mountain was simply sublime.
His act of heroism was considered sublime by the entire community.

title: profound
descriptions: having intellectual depth and insight
extending far below the surface
characterized by intensity of feeling or quality
sentences: Her speech made a profound impact on everyone listening.
The novel explores profound themes of love and loss.

title: rear
descriptions: to erect by building : CONSTRUCT
to raise upright
sentences: He took great pride in rearing his children in a loving home.
The monument reared against the sky, visible from miles away.

title: discretion
descriptions: individual choice or judgment
the quality of having or showing discernment or good judgment
sentences: At the discretion of the manager, some customers were given a refund.
He handled the sensitive issue with discretion and care.

title: combustion
descriptions: an act or instance of burning
a usually rapid chemical process (such as oxidation) that produces heat and usually light
sentences: The engine's combustion process is finely tuned for efficiency.
Improper disposal of chemicals can lead to spontaneous combustion.

title: impudent
descriptions: marked by contemptuous or cocky boldness or disregard of others : INSOLENT
lacking modesty
sentences: The impudent child talked back to adults without hesitation.
His impudent remarks earned him a reputation for being brash.

title: asylum
descriptions: an inviolable place of refuge and protection giving shelter to criminals and debtors : SANCTUARY
a place of retreat and security : SHELTER
sentences: The country granted her asylum from persecution in her homeland.
The old mansion was rumored to have been an asylum in the 1800s.

title: confine
descriptions: something (such as borders or walls) that encloses
sentences: The sick were confined to their rooms to prevent the spread of illness.
He hated the confine of the small office space.

title: tamper
descriptions: to interfere so as to weaken or change for the worse
to carry on underhand or improper negotiations (as by bribery)
sentences: Tampering with the device voids the warranty.
Evidence suggested someone had tampered with the lock.

title: tempting
descriptions: having an appeal : ENTICING
sentences: The offer was tempting, but she decided to decline.
Despite the tempting desserts, he chose the healthy option.

title: forsake
descriptions: to renounce or turn away from entirely
sentences: He vowed he would never forsake his family.
To achieve her dreams, she forsook her comfort zone.

title: deed
descriptions: something that is done
a usually illustrious act or action : FEAT, EXPLOIT
sentences: The knight was honored for his brave deeds.
Signing the deed transferred ownership of the property.
